where Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} is a constant that depends on hyper-parameters used by different methods and remains constant across global rounds, and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} is a term capturing historical training information (past local updates). We summarize the values of Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} for different FL schemes in TableÂ 1 (derivations provided in Appendix A.4-A.9). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that studies label recovery attacks in FL schemes beyond FedAvg.
In FL schemes that utilize only the gradient information computed in the current global round (e.g., FedAvg and FedProx)
ğ¡jt=ğŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}=\mathbf{0}, while for the schemes that also
rely on the past gradient information (Scaffold, FedDyn and FedDC)
ğ¡jtâ‰ ğŸsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}\not=\mathbf{0}. In any case, Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} are known to the server and may potentially be used for label recovery attacks. In our work, we rely on the procedure for label recovery from local updates discussed in the previous section to run RLU attacks on different FL schemes where Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} and ğ¡jtsuperscriptsubscriptğ¡ğ‘—ğ‘¡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t} vary from one scheme to another according to TableÂ 1.

references: A randomly initialized untrained model may be extremely vulnerable to label recovery attacks; for instance, if the server knows how the training is initialized, it does not even need an auxiliary data set to infer the parameters (e.g., ğnsubscriptğğ‘›\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}) used in the attack. To compare the performance of baseline methods with that of RLU, we conduct comprehensive experiments on untrained models across various architectures, datasets, batch-sizes and activation functions. The results, reported in TableÂ 2, demonstrate that RLU outperforms the baselines in all settings. When local training consists of a single epoch, RLU achieves near-perfect accuracy across the board in terms of both cAcc and iAcc; iRLG is a close second, outperforming other baselines. Since LLG+ assumes non-negative activation functions, its performance deteriorates significantly with Tanh and SELU. On Tiny-ImageNet, ZLG+ performs the worst among the four methods, achieving under 70%percent7070\% iAcc.

When the clients run m=10ğ‘š10m=10 local epochs, performance of all methods deteriorates (as expected based on the discussion in Section 3.2.2). Nevertheless, the results in TableÂ 2 show that RLU still outperforms the baselines, maintaining at least 84%percent8484\% cACC and 90%percent9090\% iAcc on all datasets, architectures and activation functions. While iRLG maintains solid performance on SVHN and Tiny-ImageNet, it performs significantly worse on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 (iAcc falls below 70%percent7070\%, cAcc drops below 50%percent5050\%). The results of LLG+ follow the same pattern exhibited in single epoch settings, while ZLG+ experiences significant performance deterioration on SVHN. For consistency and a comparison with the results in TableÂ 2, unless stated otherwise, in the remainder of this section the number of local epochs mğ‘šm is set to 101010.

Since the accuracy of the global model improves as the training proceeds, comparing methods in terms of attacks on untrained model becomes no longer meaningful. As discussed in Section 3.2, distribution of output logits depends on the accuracy of the model which is parameterized by mean ğnsubscriptğğ‘›\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n} and covariance ğšºnsubscriptğšºğ‘›\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n}. When the model becomes highly accurate, magnitudes of local gradients (updates) start vanishing; this, in turn, causes high sensitivity to noise and a large error in estimating the labels. All of the methods in TableÂ 2 experience performance deterioration as the model accuracy increases. To compare their robustness, we conduct extensive experiments and evaluate performance of different attack methods at different stages of training. As shown in Fig.Â 1, RLU outperforms the baselines at all training stages, achieving 80%percent8080\% iAcc when the model accuracy reaches 80%percent8080\%. For the global model achieving 90%percent9090\% training accuracy, iAcc of iRLG reaches 75.6%percent75.675.6\%, 83.3%percent83.383.3\% and 72.6%percent72.672.6\% on SVHN, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The iAcc of ZLG+ is 33.3%percent33.333.3\%, 21.1%percent21.121.1\% and 30.1%percent30.130.1\% lower than RLUâ€™s, while iRLGâ€™s trails RLU by 16.3%percent16.316.3\%, 17.3%percent17.317.3\% and 23.9%percent23.923.9\% on these three datasets, respectively. The iAcc performance of LLG+ is better than that of other prior methods but still falls significantly behind RLUâ€™s.

The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta for the SGD optimizer was set to 0.010.010.01 in all experiments reported in TableÂ 2. In order to obtain high level of data heterogeneity, we set the concentration parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha to 0.50.50.5 in the experiments on SVHN and CIFAR10; in the experiments on CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet, this parameter was set to 0.10.10.1. There are two groups of experiments in TableÂ 2; in one the number of local epochs mğ‘šm was set to 111, while in the other it was set to 101010. For the experiments involving multiple local epochs, the number of iterations Tğ‘‡T in Alg.Â 2 was set to 101010.

Here we explored the effect of data heterogeneity controlled by varying the concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha from 0.050.050.05 to 555. For a fair comparison, we set the number of local epochs to m=10ğ‘š10m=10; other settings were identical to the settings in TableÂ 2.

Similar to TableÂ 2 and TableÂ LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs mğ‘šm to 101010 in all experiments reported in TableÂ 4, FigureÂ 1 and FigureÂ 2. The concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

references: Data heterogeneity is one the main challenges in real-world applications of federated learning. Prior works on label reconstruction evaluated their proposed methods on i.i.d. data, but the evaluation on non-i.i.d. data has remained largely unexplored. references: To the best of our knowledge, prior works evaluate their methods only on FedAvg. While FedAvg is indeed the oldest and perhaps the most widely used FL scheme, a number of other FL schemes has grown to prominence yet remains largely unexplored in the context of label recovery. As discussed in Section 3.3, we provide a framework to conduct label recovery attacks on several regularization-based FL schemes that may be using various optimizers. TableÂ 4 shows the superior performance of RLU in the experiments on FedProx and SGDm. As can be seen from the table, in the experiments where Î»=0.5ğœ†0.5\lambda=0.5 and Î³=0.1ğ›¾0.1\gamma=0.1 (which leads to Ï(Ï„)â‰ˆ1superscriptğœŒğœ1\rho^{(\tau)}\approx 1), the three baselines achieve performance similar to that in their attacks on FedAvg. However, as Ï(Ï„)superscriptğœŒğœ\rho^{(\tau)} deviates from 111 when Î»=5ğœ†5\lambda=5 and Î³=0.9ğ›¾0.9\gamma=0.9, performance of the baselines severely deteriorates while RLU maintain its iAcc of at least 88%percent8888\%.

Similar to TableÂ 2 and TableÂ LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs mğ‘šm to 101010 in all experiments reported in TableÂ 4, FigureÂ 1 and FigureÂ 2. The concentration parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.
